title: Marketplace postage scams (fake AusPost links/QR codes)
summary: Scammers pose as buyers on marketplaces and send fake shipping/payment links or QR codes to steal your details.
how_it_works: Scammer contacts you as a ‘buyer’ and suggests a courier/shipping link.
You’re asked to pay a ‘postage’ fee or enter card details to receive funds.
warning_signs: Buyer insists you use a link they send (not the marketplace).
You’re asked to pay to get paid.
Link/QR code doesn’t go to the official delivery domain.
example_hooks: “Use this AusPost link to receive payment.”
“Scan this QR to arrange courier pickup.”
what_to_do: Don’t use shipping/payment links provided by strangers.
Verify with official carrier apps/sites you open yourself.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
